longdesc.p: The jQuery UI Droppable plugin makes selected elements droppable (meaning they accept being dropped on by draggables). You can specify which (individually) or which kind of draggables each will accept.
All callbacks receive two arguments: The original browser event and a prepared ui object, view below for a documentation of this object (if you name your second argument 'ui'):

ul.li: ui.draggable - current draggable element, a jQuery object.
ui.helper - current draggable helper, a jQuery object
ui.position - current position of the draggable helper { top: , left: }
ui.offset - current absolute position of the draggable helper { top: , left: }

option.name: accept
option.desc: All draggables that match the selector will be accepted. If a function is specified, the function will be called for each draggable on the page (passed as the first argument to the function), to provide a custom filter. The function should return true if the draggable should be accepted.

option.name: activeClass
option.desc: If specified, the class will be added to the droppable while an acceptable draggable is being dragged.

option.name: addClasses
option.desc: If set to false, will prevent the ui-droppable class from being added. This may be desired as a performance optimization when calling .droppable() init on many hundreds of elements.

option.name: disabled
option.desc: Disables the droppable if set to true.

option.name: greedy
option.desc: If true, will prevent event propagation on nested droppables.

option.name: hoverClass
option.desc: If specified, the class will be added to the droppable while an acceptable draggable is being hovered.

option.name: scope
option.desc: Used to group sets of draggable and droppable items, in addition to droppable's accept option. A draggable with the same scope value as a droppable will be accepted.

option.name: tolerance
option.desc:
Specifies which mode to use for testing whether a draggable is 'over' a droppable. Possible values: 'fit', 'intersect', 'pointer', 'touch'.
'''fit''': draggable overlaps the droppable entirely
'''intersect''': draggable overlaps the droppable at least 50%
'''pointer''': mouse pointer overlaps the droppable
'''touch''': draggable overlaps the droppable any amount

event.name: activate
event.desc: This event is triggered any time an accepted draggable starts dragging. This can be useful if you want to make the droppable 'light up' when it can be dropped on.

event.name: create
event.desc: This event is triggered when the droppable is created.

event.name: deactivate
event.desc: This event is triggered any time an accepted draggable stops dragging.

event.name: over
event.desc: This event is triggered as an accepted draggable is dragged 'over' (within the tolerance of) this droppable.

event.name: out
event.desc: This event is triggered when an accepted draggable is dragged out (within the tolerance of) this droppable.

event.name: drop
event.desc: This event is triggered when an accepted draggable is dropped 'over' (within the tolerance of) this droppable. In the callback, $(this) represents the droppable the draggable is dropped on. ui.draggable represents the draggable.

method.name: option
method.desc: Get or set any droppable option. If no value is specified, will act as a getter.

method.name: option
method.desc: Set multiple droppable options at once by providing an options object.

example.desc: Makes the div droppable (a drop target for a draggable).
example.inhead:
<style type="text/css">
    #draggable { width: 75px; height: 25px; background: silver; padding: 10px; }
    #droppable { position: absolute; left: 250px; top: 0; width: 125px; height: 75px; background: gray; color: white; padding: 10px; }
  </style>
